Award.AwardTitle: Hazards SEES Type 2: WIFIRE: A Scalable Data-Driven Monitoring, Dynamic Prediction and Resilience Cyberinfrastructure for Wildfires

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of California at San Diego (UCSD) is awarded a grant to build an end-to-end cyberinfrastructure (CI), called WIFIRE, for real-time and data-driven simulation, prediction and visualization of wildfire behavior. San Diego Supercomputer Center (SDSC) and Calit2's Qualcomm Institute will build this integrated CI system for supporting social-ecological resilience to the changing fire ecology regime in the face of urban dynamics and climate change, together with collaborators from UCSD's Jacobs School of Engineering and UMD's Department of Fire Protection Engineering. The WIFIRE CI integrates networked observations, e.g., heterogeneous satellite data and real-time remote sensor data, with computational techniques in signal processing, visualization, modeling and data assimilation to provide a scalable, technological, and educational solution to monitor weather patterns to predict a wildfire's Rate of Spread. Our collaborative WIFIRE team of scientists, engineers, technologists, government policy managers, private industry, and firefighters will architect and implement CI pathways that enable joint innovation for wildfire management. Scientific workflows will be used as an integrative distributed programming model and will simplify the implementation of engineering modules for data-driven simulation, prediction and visualization while allowing integration with large-scale computing facilities. WIFIRE will be scalable to users with different skill-levels via specialized web interfaces and user-specified alerts for environmental events broadcasted to receivers before, during and after a wildfire. The approach is scalable which allows many sensors to be subjected to user-specified data processing algorithms to generate threshold alerts within seconds. Integration of this sensor data into both rapidly available fire image data and models will better enable situational awareness, responses and decision support at local, state, national, and international levels.

The products of WIFIRE will be initially disseminated to project collaborators (SDG&E, CAL FIRE, USFS), covering academic, private, and government laboratories while generating value to emergency officials, and consequently to the general public. WIFIRE may be used by government agencies in the future to save lives and property during wildfire events, test the effectiveness of response and evacuation scenarios before they occur and assess the effectiveness of high-density sensor networks in improving fire and weather predictions. WIFIRE's high-density network, therefore, will serve as a testbed for future applications worldwide. The team is inclusive across a spectrum of collaborators and will create an open-source CI environment with intuitive workflows that lead to reusable software components for a wide range of science and engineering disciplines that can be extended to secondary education. Results are disseminated via an interactive website at SDSC in which students from high school to graduate level can participate in uploading their own data logging, data processing or data-driven alerts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
WIFIRE (http://wifire.ucsd.edu) built an end-to-end cyberinfrastructure for real-time and data-driven simulation, prediction, and visualization of wildfire behavior. WIFIRE developed interfaces for ingesting and visualizing high-density data and tools to improve fire and weather predictions, so that they can be easily used by the fire research community and fire fighting agencies. The solutions are available on the WIFIRE website and executable through the open-source Kepler Workflows and web servers.  Users, e..g, firefighters, seismologists and wildlife biologists, can define the sets of sensors and parameters suitable to their needs, and insert them as functions into the real-time data processing system. WIFIRE also supports the broader public to view information related to situational awareness during wildfire events.

 

In partnership with the Los Angeles Fire Department, the WIFIRE team developed an operational tool called Firemap (https://firemap.sdsc.edu) for real-time visualization, fire behavior modeling and forecasting, and what-if analyses for potential fires. Firemap enables simple execution of fire models with options for running ensembles by taking the information uncertainty into account. The results are easily viewable sharable, repeatable, and can be animated as a time series.

 

The intuitive user interface and situational awareness maps provided by Firemap has been impactful in both operational, educational and public settings. Many firefighters are using Firemap throughout the State of California informally, and more than 120 organizations and individuals have reached out to WIFIRE for help and collaboration. As an example for the system’s potential public impact, through word of mouth in social media, the Firemap tool was accessed by 800 thousand public users over 8 million times to view information related to the devastating wildfires in California (CA) throughout Fall 2017.

 

WIFIRE performed machine learning techniques on weather station data to identify weather patterns associated with Santa Ana conditions. Weather-related measurements such as temperature, air pressure, wind direction, etc. are captured by sensors on each weather station in the HPWREN network.  These measurements are analyzed using k-means clustering to identify different weather patterns, and to specifically detect Santa Ana patterns. Santa Ana winds bring gusty, hot, dry conditions that can greatly exacerbate the dangers of wildfires. It is thus important to be able to detect Santa Ana conditions to aid with firefighting efforts.

 

The WIFIRE project also developed extensible capabilities to generate and curate vegetation maps using high resolution imagery and machine learning in computer vision techniques. Through ongoing partnerships with DigitalGlobe and Planet to collect California statewide high-resolution imagery daily in real time, the team creates accurate and up-to-date vegetation maps. Up-to-date information on vegetation and fuel build up is critical for modeling wildfire rate of speed, potential burn areas, and effectively targeting prevention strategies and identify local needs for vegetation management.

 

WIFIRE team also developed a new prototype wildfire spread model based on data assimilation and aimed at forecasting the fireline location; this prototype has been validated against historical field-scale prescribed fires. Data assimilation is an emerging and powerful tool towards real-time monitoring of flame propagation for wildland fire applications. The key idea is to train models with past measurements in order to improve model predictions: in the present context, the idea is to regularly update the state and/or parameters of a wildland fire spread model using observed firelines extracted from infrared images in order to improve a forecast on future fire locations. The performance of the prototype data-driven wildfire spread model has been evaluated against data from medium-size experiments (at the kilometer/several-minutes scale) in terms of accuracy of the predictions (i.e., the predicted fireline location) versus the frequency of data assimilation (i.e., the frequency of fireline observations). Our new algorithms were tested against a prescribed fire experiment called FireFlux and a large-scale wildfire in Yosemite National Park, the Rim fire.


Early on in the project, WIFIRE organized a workshop entitled “Towards Data-Driven Operational Wildfire Spread Modeling” that took place on January 12-13 2015 at the University of California San Diego (http://wifire.ucsd.edu/?q=content/wifire-2015-modeling-workshop). The workshop was focused on data-driven wildfire modeling and brought together key representatives of the wildfire research community, the geosciences community and the fire science community. A workshop report was written and published.
